===Development=== In a 2006 interview with [[CNN-IBN]], Madhur Bhandarkar said that he was preparing to make a film about the fashion industry; he thought the lack of Indian films on this subject prompted him to do so.{{cite web|title=Fashion next on Madhur's film list |url=http://content.ibnlive.in.com/article/03-Sep-2006movies-news/fashion-next-on-madhurs-film-list-20489-8.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615235851/http://content.ibnlive.in.com/article/03-Sep-2006movies-news/fashion-next-on-madhurs-film-list-20489-8.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 June 2013 |author=Sengupta, Hindol |publisher=[[CNN-IBN]] |date=4 September 2006 |accessdate=27 April 2013 }} He said he was fascinated with the industry, the models and their lives outside the ramp walks, saying "I was amazed at the overwhelming attention given to the fashion Industry by the media and the public. I thought the idea of delving deep into the fashion world was very interesting and intriguing."{{cite web|title='Kangana's role is not based on Geetanjali's life' |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2008/oct/27mb.htm |author=Chaudhary, Swati R |publisher=[[Rediff.com]] |date=27 October 2008 |accessdate=1 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928050537/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2008/oct/27mb.htm |archivedate=28 September 2013 |df= }} He was excited about depicting the people behind the ramp because most people are unfamiliar with the fashion world. Bhandarkar, who is known for studying his subject matter to make his films as realistic as possible, researched the fashion industry for nearly eight months, attending fashion events and shows. He spoke with designers, buyers, choreographers and models.{{cite web|title=Fashion will be my last woman-oriented film |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Entertainment/Fashion-will-be-my-last-woman-oriented-film/Article1-255865.aspx |author=Jha, Subhash K. |work=[[Hindustan Times]] |date=5 November 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005111222/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Entertainment/Fashion-will-be-my-last-woman-oriented-film/Article1-255865.aspx |archivedate= 5 October 2013 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Bhandarkar researching for film on fashion fraternity |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1121950671.html |work=Hindustan Times |publisher=Accessed by [[Highbeam Research]] |date=4 September 2006 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402151338/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1121950671.html |archivedate= 2 April 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Beyond the ramp... |url=http://www.hindu.com/fr/2008/10/31/stories/2008103150050100.htm |author=Zaman, Rana Siddiqui |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928063043/http://www.hindu.com/fr/2008/10/31/stories/2008103150050100.htm |archivedate=28 September 2013 |df= }} Several media publications reported that the film was inspired by the lives of fashion models such as Shivani Kapur, Geetanjali Nagpal, [[Kate Moss]] and Alicia Raut; however, Bhandarkar stated that the story is fictional and does not resemble anyone's life.{{cite web|title=Madhur's attempt to be realistic|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-06-30/news-interviews/27758076_1_drug-abuse-priyanka-chopra-blood-test|author=Lalwani, Vickey|work=The Times of India|date=30 June 2008|accessdate=14 June 2013}} The media also reported that the film revolved around two homosexual fashion designers; Bhandarkar denied these rumours, saying the film did not revolve around male characters but had female protagonists.{{cite web|title=Bhandarkar's Fashion isn't about two gay designers |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Entertainment/Bhandarkar-s-Fashion-isn-t-about-two-gay-designers/Article1-252783.aspx |agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service]] |work=Hindustan Times |date=16 October 2007 |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005111226/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Entertainment/Bhandarkar-s-Fashion-isn-t-about-two-gay-designers/Article1-252783.aspx |archivedate=5 October 2013 |df=dmy }} ===Casting and characters=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | footer = Chopra ''(top)'', Ranaut ''(middle)'' and Godse ''(bottom)'' were cast in the central roles to portray models in the film | width = | image1 = Priyanka nikon event1.jpg | width1 = 180 | alt1 = a woman looking forward, posing for the camera | caption1 = | image2 = Kangana Ranaut.jpg | width2 = 180 | alt2 = a woman looking forward, posing for the camera | caption2 = | image3 = Mugdha Godse supporting Sandip Soparrkar's 'Dance for a cause'.jpg | width3 = 180 | alt3 = a woman looking forward, posing for the camera | caption3 = }} Casting began in October 2007, when Priyanka Chopra signed to play the lead role in the film.{{cite web|title=Priyanka Chopra bags lead role in Madhur's film|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-10-06/news-interviews/27961905_1_priyanka-chopra-bags-madhur-bhandarkar-indian-films|author=Buragohain, Gautam|work=The Times of India|date=6 October 2007|accessdate=27 April 2013}} Chopra initially refused the role, feeling she would not be able to do it justice. Six months later, she agreed to appear in the film because of Bhandarkar's confidence in her.{{cite web|title=Style watch: Priyanka wears 137 outfits in Fashion |url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2008/oct/301008fashionpriyankachopra.htm |work=[[Mid Day]] |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=13 March 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906051257/http://www.mid-day.com/news/2008/oct/301008fashionpriyankachopra.htm |archivedate= 6 September 2013 |df= }} The media reported that Chopra was unhappy with the first draft of the film and wanted script changes before signing the film. Bhandarkar was also unhappy with the first draft and agreed to rewrite the script. Kangana Ranaut was cast as the film's second lead; she was pleased with the script and found it challenging, interesting and exciting.{{cite web|title=Kangana not insecure about acting with Priyanka |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1130342/report-kangana-not-insecure-about-acting-with-priyanka |author=Jha, Subhash K. |work=[[Daily News and Analysis]] |date=28 October 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526061545/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1130342/report-kangana-not-insecure-about-acting-with-priyanka |archivedate=26 May 2013 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Kangana Ranaut on Fashion and drug use!|url=http://www.sify.com/mobile/movies/Kangana-ranaut-on-fashion-and-drug-use-imagegallery-bollywood-jdwmSXhfccj.html|publisher=[[Sify]]|date=22 October 2008|accessdate=2 June 2013}} In December 2007, Arbaaz Khan and Arjan Bajwa were cast opposite Chopra.{{cite web|title=Arbaaz's big break opposite Priyanka, Kangana |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1140989/report-arbaaz-s-big-break-opposite-priyanka-kangana |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |work=Daily News and Analysis |date=23 December 2007 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927163647/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1140989/report-arbaaz-s-big-break-opposite-priyanka-kangana |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Bhandarkar finds his hero for Fashion |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Chunk-HT-UI-EntertainmentSectionPage-Bollwood/Bhandarkar-finds-his-hero-for-Fashion/Article1-265162.aspx |author=Dubey, Rachana |work=Hindustan Times |date=24 December 2007 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005111238/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Chunk-HT-UI-EntertainmentSectionPage-Bollwood/Bhandarkar-finds-his-hero-for-Fashion/Article1-265162.aspx |archivedate=5 October 2013 |df=dmy }} After confirming the principal cast, the media reported that Bhandarkar was having difficulty casting the male roles, including that of a homosexual clothing designer.{{cite web|title=Bhandarkar's 'Fashion' runs into casting trouble |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1143535/report-bhandarkar-s-fashion-runs-into-casting-trouble |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |work=Daily News and Analysis |date=7 January 2013 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526080408/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1143535/report-bhandarkar-s-fashion-runs-into-casting-trouble |archivedate=26 May 2013 |df= }} Samir Soni and Harsh Chhaya were cast as the homosexual designers,{{cite web|title=Curiosity about Fashion scares Bhandarkar |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Bollwood/Curiosity-about-Fashion-scares-Bhandarkar/Article1-274387.aspx |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |work=Hindustan Times |date=7 February 2008 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005111234/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Bollwood/Curiosity-about-Fashion-scares-Bhandarkar/Article1-274387.aspx |archivedate=5 October 2013 |df=dmy }} and model Mugdha Godse was cast in a supporting role.{{cite web|title=Mugdha Godse learns acting!|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-02-05/news-interviews/27759798_1_anupam-kher-priyanka-chopra-mugdha-godse|work=The Times of India|date=5 February 2008|accessdate=2 May 2013}} According to Godse, Bhandarkar offered her a part when they were shooting a jewellery advertisement; a year later, she agreed to appear in the film.{{cite web|title=I HAVE A GOOD BODY |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1080916/jsp/entertainment/story_9838698.jsp |author=Chakraborty, Saionee |work=The Telegraph |date=16 September 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927170441/http://www.telegraphindia.com/1080916/jsp/entertainment/story_9838698.jsp |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df= }} The ''[[Hindustan Times]]'' said that several models and designers played themselves, giving the film the appearance of a documentary.{{cite web|title=Bhandarkar's 'Fashion' to star models in real life roles |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1232625881.html |work=Hindustan Times, accessed via [[Highbeam Research]] |date=14 March 2007 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140629084239/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1232625881.html |archivedate=29 June 2014 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Bhandarkar gets top notch names for 'Fashion' |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1510432651.html |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |work=Hindustan Times, accessed via [[Highbeam Research]] |date=14 July 2008 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140629084237/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1510432651.html |archivedate=29 June 2014 |df= }} Chopra said she studied method acting to make her character seem real. The actress said that her character is determined and added, "While her father wants her to become an accountant she aspires to become the leading model in fashion industry".{{cite web|title='Fashion' is Madhur's most positive film: Priyanka Chopra |url=https://www.outlookindia.com/newswire/story/fashion-is-madhurs-most-positive-film-priyanka-chopra/626223|work=[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]] |date=29 October 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2013|archiveurl=https://www.outlookindia.com/newswire/story/fashion-is-madhurs-most-positive-film-priyanka-chopra/626223|archivedate=12 February 2018}} Addressing rumours that the film was an exposé of the fashion industry, she said, "It is nothing like that. Whatever problems that come up to my character in the film are not because of the profession but because of the choices that my character makes in her life". Ranaut said, "In this script my character is such that you get to express you emotions, emotions that you have never delivered before in front of the camera. So when I heard the script, it was something new and much more challenging, more interesting and exciting." Godse said that she accepted her role in the film because she identified with her character, Janet Sequira, whom she described as "outgoing, vibrant, bold and outspoken". Arjan Bajwa described his character, an aspiring fashion model, as uncompromising, achieving success in his own way.{{cite web|title=Steamy scenes with Priyanka over-hyped |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Chunk-HT-UI-EntertainmentSectionPage-Bollwood/Steamy-scenes-with-Priyanka-over-hyped/Article1-345576.aspx |author=Saini, Minakshi |work=Hindustan Times |date=18 October 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005111244/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Chunk-HT-UI-EntertainmentSectionPage-Bollwood/Steamy-scenes-with-Priyanka-over-hyped/Article1-345576.aspx |archivedate=5 October 2013 |df=dmy }} Samir Soni found his role as a closeted fashion designer very challenging, requiring research to flesh out the character and his personality. Soni's greatest challenge was to avoid a stereotypical homosexual character, instead subtly expressing his sexuality in his personality and relationships with the film's other characters.{{cite web|title=Being gay is as normal as being straight: Samir Soni |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Entertainment/Being-gay-is-as-normal-as-being-straight-Samir-Soni/Article1-346600.aspx |author=Dey, Sudipta |work=Hindustan Times |date=23 October 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005111242/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Entertainment/Being-gay-is-as-normal-as-being-straight-Samir-Soni/Article1-346600.aspx |archivedate=5 October 2013 |df=dmy }} ===Styling=== Rita Dhody and Narendra Kumar were chosen to style the film's characters.{{cite web|title=Priyanka is happy!|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-12-26/news-interviews/27963371_1_priyanka-chopra-dress-designer-duggu-and-i-shot|work=The Times of India|date=26 December 2007|accessdate=26 May 2013}} Dhody said it took nearly two months for UTV and Bhandarkar to persuade her to help design the film; she found the job challenging because she had to make everything as authentic as possible.{{cite web|title=The movie isn’t about a good skirt |url=http://www.punemirror.in/article/55/20081102200811020358333666132a010/The-movie-isn%E2%80%99t-about-a-good-skirt.html?pageno=9 |author=Aggarwal, Veda |work=Pune Mirror |date=2 November 2008 |accessdate=26 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928071216/http://www.punemirror.in/article/55/20081102200811020358333666132a010/The-movie-isn%E2%80%99t-about-a-good-skirt.html?pageno=9 |archivedate=28 September 2013 |df=dmy }} Chopra had to wear 137 costumes in the film because her character passed through five phases.{{cite web|title=How Fashion stars were styled... |url=http://www.masala.com/7700-how-fashion-stars-were-styled |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |work=Masala |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927081250/http://www.masala.com/7700-how-fashion-stars-were-styled |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df= }} Initially, she was a "hep" character with brightly coloured, matching attire. Her make-up becomes lighter as she becomes a model and later a supermodel. When her career falters, Chopra's look becomes softer, demonstrating her character's lack of concern about her appearance before she returns to Mumbai. According to Dhody, Chopra's look is "very contemporary and a very much today's look, but my idea was to streamline and take it to the classic side [rather] than making it trend-based". Ranaut's character was designed to make audiences feel sympathy for her. Dhody gave her short dresses with low necklines, conveying the image of a supermodel comfortable with her body; during her low phase, she is shown in long T-shirts. Godse, whose character is a failed model, has a carefree look. Dhody said, "Godse's look in the film is a fusion of rock and a grunge to give her the survivor look as a B-grade model, making her more chic and glamorous." She wears low-waisted trousers, chains and ankle boots. Details of jewellery, clothes, colour and accessories outline the characters; everything had to be sychronised and complement each other to create an authentic look. Dhody said, "We didn't try to sensationalise it by making it more bling- or costume-based. I had to restrain myself from going overboard due to Bhandarkar's reservations". The film's narrative included 11 character-based ramp shows. ===Filming=== Principal photography commenced in December 2007, and the film was shot extensively in Mumbai.{{cite web|title=Fashion is 70% complete: Madhur |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/boxoffice.php?id=14649476&cid=14472478 |publisher=Sify |date=15 April 2008 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622095859/http://www.sify.com/movies/boxoffice.php?id=14649476&cid=14472478 |archivedate=22 June 2013 |df= }} The scene with Ranaut's wardrobe malfunction during a ramp walk was filmed in late January 2008 at [[Mehboob Studios]], [[Bandra]]. While filming the scene, only essential cast and crew members{{mdash}}included Bhandarkar and his cinematographer{{mdash}}were present; according to Bhandarkar, it was a sensitive scene and a sensitive issue.{{cite web|title=Kangana Ranaut: Baring responsibility|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-02-01/news-interviews/27782891_1_Kangana-ranaut-wardrobe-priyanka-chopra|author=Lalwani, Vickey|work=The Times of India|date=1 February 2008|accessdate=2 June 2013}} Chopra had to gain {{convert|6|kg}} as a girl from the Punjab, and then lose it as a model; she had five "looks" in the film, connoting the phases through which her character passes. Although the media spread rumours that Chopra was starving herself to reduce her weight to that of a supermodel, she said that her appearance was achieved with two months of training and a disciplined diet.{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1153009/report-priyanka-chopra-not-starving-herself-for-fashion |title=Priyanka Chopra not starving herself for 'Fashion' |work=DNA |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |date=26 February 2008 |accessdate=5 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927170338/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1153009/report-priyanka-chopra-not-starving-herself-for-fashion |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df= }} The film's climactic scene in which Chopra walks the ramp at [[Paris Fashion Week]] was supposed to be filmed in Paris, with the [[Eiffel Tower]] as a backdrop,{{cite web|title=Priyanka: ‘Fashion’able in Paris|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-06-15/news-interviews/27762636_1_madhur-bhandarkar-priyanka-chopra-chandni-bar|work=The Times of India|date=15 June 2008|accessdate=2 May 2013}} but Bhandarkar could not shoot there.{{cite web|title=Controversies follow me: Madhur|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-09-24/news-interviews/27949757_1_national-award-expensive-film-great-expectations|author=Verma, Ritu|work=The Times of India|date=24 September 2008|accessdate=14 June 2013}} Instead, the scene uses some footage from the actual fashion show. In mid-August 2008, key scenes with Chopra, Raj Babbar and Kiran Juneja{{mdash}}Chopra's character's parents{{mdash}}were filmed in Chandigarh for authenticity; Bhandarkar said, "we wanted to bring the essence of the city alive in the scenes".{{cite web|title=Its raining awards on Madhur Bhandarkar |url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/its-raining-awards-on-madhur-bhandarkar/348876/ |author=Bollywood Hungama |work=The Financial Express |date=14 August 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130930004657/http://www.financialexpress.com/news/its-raining-awards-on-madhur-bhandarkar/348876 |archivedate=30 September 2013 |df=dmy }} The director said the film took about 106 days to complete, compared with his 45-day average. ==Themes and allusions== [[File:Madhur Bhandarkar FilmiTadka.JPG|thumb|left|upright|''Fashion'' was Bhandarkar's fourth women-centric film to win widespread praise]] ''Fashion'' is Bhandarkar's fourth [[woman's film|women-centric film]] after ''[[Chandni Bar]]'' (2001), ''[[Page 3 (film)|Page 3]]'' (2005) and ''[[Corporate (2006 film)|Corporate]]'' (2006) to earn widespread praise for their strong, independent female characters.{{cite web|title=Winning in fashion |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1081116/jsp/graphiti/story_10114663.jsp |author=Mukherjee, Promita |work=The Telegraph |date=16 November 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928025710/http://www.telegraphindia.com/1081116/jsp/graphiti/story_10114663.jsp |archivedate=28 September 2013 |df= }} According to ''[[The Times of India]]'', ''Fashion'' "is not about cliches alone and manages to transcend them with its moving tale of three women who try to maintain their honour, dignity, [and] identity in a cruel world that spills over with grime behind the glamour. The film not only takes you behind the psychedelic ramp, it travels through the dark inner recesses of the three lead characters, laying bare their strengths and weaknesses; their fears and hopes; their dreams and nightmares".{{cite web|title=Fashion Review |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/Fashion/movie-review/3659730.cms |author=Kazmi, Nikhat |work=The Times of India |date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140125062908/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/Fashion/movie-review/3659730.cms |archivedate=25 January 2014 |df= }} Ananya Bhattacharya of [[Zee News]] said that the film "went on to speak volumes about women, their aspirations and the dark side-effects of over-ambition". In an interview with the ''Hindustan Times'', Chopra said that the film is "an emotional tale and the story of three girls ... [which] shows female bonding in a beautiful way ... ".{{cite web|title=C u later |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Fashion/C-u-later/Article1-345062.aspx |author=Jain, Princy |work=Hindustan Times |date=16 October 2008 |accessdate=1 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006102946/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Fashion/C-u-later/Article1-345062.aspx |archivedate=6 October 2013 |df=dmy }} Reviewer Kriti Verma of ''Headlines India'' said that the movie "shows every bit about the life of models and bring the inside secrets of [the] fashion industry. It has everything{{mdash}}fashion weeks, casting couch, drugs, abuses, gay designers, bitching."{{cite web|title=Fashion: Review |url=http://headlinesindia.mapsofindia.com/lifestyle/entertainment/moviereview/fashion.html |author=Verma, Kriti |work=Headlines India |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120131044236/http://headlinesindia.mapsofindia.com/lifestyle/entertainment/moviereview/fashion.html |archivedate=31 January 2012 |df= }} Taran Adarsh from ''[[Bollywood Hungama]]'' wrote, "the narrative is inevitably filled with lots of glam-n-glitz moments. The fashion shows, the stunning models, the superb styling, the vibrant colours and the behind the scenes drama is worth every penny spent on the ticket."{{cite web|title=Review: Fashion |url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/criticreview/id/538488 |author=Adarsh, Taran |publisher=[[Bollywood Hungama]] |date=29 October 2008 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309213914/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/criticreview/id/538488 |archivedate= 9 March 2014 |df= }} A reviewer from Sify.com found the film's depiction of fashion industry "superficial"; noting that the film does not talk about the clothing, the creativity, or the passion for work in the fashion industry.{{cite web|title=Review: Fashion is superficial |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/review-fashion-is-superficial-review-bollywood-14787408.html |author=Chopra, Sonia |publisher=Sify |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615164837/http://www.sify.com/movies/review-fashion-is-superficial-review-bollywood-14787408.html |archivedate=15 June 2013 |df= }} However, according to Bhandarkar the film was "not about [the] fashion industry as such. It only has fashion as a backdrop. The film is more about the story of models, designers and people. And it is on aspects like the personal story, the individual story, their ups and downs, their journey that I tried to capture."{{cite web|title=Every film I make is like experimental cinema |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Entertainment/Every-film-I-make-is-like-experimental-cinema/Article1-348053.aspx |author=Bhuyan, Aroonim |work=Hindustan Times |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=1 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006102950/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Entertainment/Every-film-I-make-is-like-experimental-cinema/Article1-348053.aspx |archivedate=6 October 2013 |df=dmy }} Critics also said that the film explores drug abuse, homosexuality and gay relationships.{{cite web|title=Bhandarkar takes a long, hard look at the fashion world|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/bhandarkar-takes-a-long-hard-look-at-the-fashion-world/378500/0 |last=Shailaja |first=Bajpai |work=The Indian Express|date=27 October 2008|accessdate=14 June 2013}}{{cite web|title=Gay in Bollywood |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1081102/jsp/7days/story_10050779.jsp |author=Pradhan, Bharathi S. |work=The Telegraph |date=2 November 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928030432/http://www.telegraphindia.com/1081102/jsp/7days/story_10050779.jsp |archivedate=28 September 2013 |df= }} Designer Vineet Bahl complained about the male characters, most of whom are portrayed as "gay designers and exploitative agency owners". He said, "Bhandarkar could have done without gross generalisations. It makes the movie shallow and over-dramatic". The film alludes several times to actual incidents, including a scene where Bhandarkar appears at a fashion show to research his upcoming film on the fashion industry. One of the models looking at him says, "Oh that's Madhur Bhandarkar, the realistic filmmaker. Now he is going to expose the fashion world."{{cite web|title=Madhur does a cameo as himself in Fashion |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/madhur-does-a-cameo-as-himself-in-fashion/380787/ |author=Chakrabarti, Paromita |work=The Indian Express |date=3 November 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207011916/http://www.indianexpress.com/news/madhur-does-a-cameo-as-himself-in-fashion/380787/ |archivedate= 7 December 2008 |df= }} It is taken from the Bhandarkar's experiences while researching the subjects of his films. ''[[The Indian Express]]'' said that Chopra's character, who indulges in drug and alcohol abuse and undergoes rehabilitation, resembles the life of British-educated model [[Shivani Kapur]], who had similar experiences. The scene in which Ranaut's character's top slips off during a ramp walk resembles the experience of [[Carol Gracias]] at the 2006 [[Lakme Fashion Week]]. ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Fashion | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Salim-Sulaiman]] | cover = | border = yes | alt = The poster showing three women, looking forward in confidence, with light pink themed colour in the background | caption = Soundtrack cover | released = {{Start date|df=y|2008|09|11}} | recorded = 2008 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Film soundtrack|Feature film soundtrack]] | length = {{Duration|m=47|s=26}} | language = [[Hindi language|Hindi]] | label = [[Super Cassettes Industries T-Series|T-Series]] | producer = | prev_title = [[Roadside Romeo]] | prev_year = 2008 | next_title = [[Rab Ne Bana Di Jodi]] | next_year = 2008 }} The ''Fashion'' soundtrack album was composed by [[Salim-Sulaiman]] and the lyrics were written by Irfan Siddiqui. [[Sandeep Nath]] appeared as a guest lyricist for "Fashion Ka Jalwa". The soundtrack contains four original songs, one theme and five remixes. The music was released by Bhandarkar and the cast on 11 September 2008 at the [[Siddhivinayak Temple, Mumbai|Siddhivinayak Temple]] in Mumbai. The cast played the film's title song, offering their first CD to [[Ganesha]].{{cite web|title='Fashion's' music launched in Mumbai temple |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/fashions-music-launched-in-mumbai-temple/73402-8.html |author=Panja, Amrita |publisher=CNN-IBN |date=12 September 2008 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010000754/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/fashions-music-launched-in-mumbai-temple/73402-8.html |archivedate=10 October 2013 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Madhur’s ‘fashion’ fundas|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-09-15/news-interviews/27926615_1_madhur-bhandarkar-music-priyanka-chopra|work=The Times of India|date=15 September 2008|accessdate=27 April 2013}} ''Fashion''{{'}}s soundtrack received favourable reviews from critics. The ''Hindustan Times'' rated the album 3.5 out of 5 and said, "It's very hard to find anything wrong with the album. Salim-Suleiman have done a wonderful job as composers and have brought out the essence of the movie in a remarkable way. Irfan has come out with great lyrics and every singer has given his or her best shot".{{cite web|title=Music Review: Fashion |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/IndiaSectionPage/Entertainment/Music-Review-Fashion/Article1-342990.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615235821/http://www.hindustantimes.com/IndiaSectionPage/Entertainment/Music-Review-Fashion/Article1-342990.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 June 2013 |author=Menon, Meghna |work=Hindustan Times |date=7 October 2008 |accessdate=27 April 2013 }} Joginder Tuteja of Bollywood Hungama described the album as "a winner all the way", and said, "Madhur Bhandarkar films haven't been known for their music, even though the albums of Corporate and Page 3 still saw some sales on the stands. However, Fashion is all set to break the jinx while turning out to be the first Madhur Bhandarkar film ever to boast of a truly mass as well as class appealing score".{{cite web|title=Fashion: Music Review |url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/musiccriticreview/id/538488 |author=Tuteja, Joginder |publisher=Bollywood Hungama |date=20 September 2008 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924134847/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/musiccriticreview/id/538488 |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df= }} Sukanya Verma of [[Rediff.com]] rated the album three out of five, and said that the film offers a well-designed mix of trendy tunes and refined melodies.{{cite web|title=Fashionably in sync Irfan Siddiqui | length10 = 4:02 }} ==Marketing and release== The film's trailer was unveiled on 17 July 2008 in Mumbai and was received warmly by critics and audiences.{{cite web|title=Madhur Bhandarkar’s ‘Fashion’ unveiled in Mumbai |url=http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/movies/madhur-bhandarkar-s-fashion-unveiled-in-mumbai_5844.htm |publisher=Zee News |date=17 July 2008 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607210915/http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/movies/madhur-bhandarkar-s-fashion-unveiled-in-mumbai_5844.htm |archivedate= 7 June 2013 |df= }} Emphasizing its theme, the lead female cast walked the ramp at fashion shows to promote the film. ''Fashion'' was also promoted at the Lakme Fashion Week, where Chopra, Ranaut and Godse walked the ramp.{{cite web|title=Lakme Fashion Week gets off to weak start in Mumbai |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Lakme+Fashion+Week+gets+off+to+weak+start+in+Mumbai/1/18182.html |author=Motihar, Jhilmil |work=[[India Today]] |date=20 October 2008 |accessdate=3 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402113306/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Lakme%20Fashion%20Week%20gets%20off%20to%20weak%20start%20in%20Mumbai/1/18182.html |archivedate= 2 April 2015 |df= }} Made on a budget of {{INRConvert|180|m|nolink=yes}}, ''Fashion'' earned {{INRConvert|85|m|nolink=yes}}, and before release recouped half its cost from tie-ins with brands including [[Reebok]], [[Lenovo]], [[Sunsilk]] and [[LG|LG Electronics]]. Products from these brands were showcased in the film and the brands promoted the film in their advertising.{{cite web|title='Fashion' earns Rs.85 mn from in-film advertising |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/009200810161632.htm |agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service]] |work=The Hindu |date=16 October 2008 |accessdate=31 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110135738/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/009200810161632.htm |archivedate=10 November 2012 |df= }} Bhandarkar expressed disappointment about the [[Central Board of Film Certification|Censor Board for Film Certification]]'s decision to grant the film an "[[Central Board of Film Certification#Current certificates|A]]" certificate{{mdash}}meant for viewers 18 years or older{{mdash}}instead of the "[[Central Board of Film Certification#Current certificates|U/A]]" certificate that he had expected. His previous films received U/A certification despite adult content. According to them, their new guidelines did not allow ''Fashion'' a U/A certification. The board was willing to issue a U/A certificate after several cuts; Bhandarkar refused and accepted the A certificate since the scenes in question were crucial to the narrative. Before its release, the Delhi Commission for Women (DCW) asked Bhandarkar to screen the film before its release due to its concern that Ranaut's character was based on [[Geetanjali Nagpal]]{{mdash}}a former high-profile fashion model found begging, bedraggled and mentally unbalanced on the streets of Delhi in 2007.{{cite news|title=Flashback for a model who fell off the catwalk |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/flashback-for-a-model-who-fell-off-the-catwalk-980267.html |first=Andrew |last=Buncombe |work=The Independent |location=London |date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=27 September 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219233036/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/flashback-for-a-model-who-fell-off-the-catwalk-980267.html |archivedate=19 December 2013 |df= }} Nagpal was helped by the DCW, which did not want anyone profiting from her life.{{cite web|title=Girl, interrupted |url=http://www.ahmedabadmirror.com/printarticle.aspx?page=comments&action=add§id=13&contentid=2008102420081024022639161a87a9e7c&subsite= |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615235939/http://www.ahmedabadmirror.com/printarticle.aspx?page=comments&action=add§id=13&contentid=2008102420081024022639161a87a9e7c&subsite= |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 June 2013 |author=Lalwani, Vickey |work=Ahemdabad Mirror |date=24 October 2013 |accessdate=2 June 2013 }} Bhandarkar narrated a summary of the film's plot at the DCW office, which satisfied the commission that there was no reference to Nagpal. A screening of the film was also held for the commission.{{cite web|title='Fashion' not on Gitanjali, says Madhur Bhandarkar|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-10-28/delhi/27946270_1_madhur-bhandarkar-film-barkha-singh|work=The Times of India|date=28 October 2008|accessdate=2 June 2013}} The film was originally scheduled for release on 14 November 2008, but this clashed with the release of Chopra's film ''[[Dostana (2008 film)|Dostana]]''{{cite web|title=Harman and Priyanka to clash at box office |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Bollwood/Harman-and-Priyanka-to-clash-at-box-office/Article1-325030.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615235941/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Bollwood/Harman-and-Priyanka-to-clash-at-box-office/Article1-325030.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 June 2013 |author=Kotwani, Hiren |work=Hindustan Times |date=19 July 2008 |accessdate=3 May 2013 }} and ''Fashion'' was released 29 October ([[Diwali]]) on 700 screens worldwide.{{cite web|title=Fashion to arrive with 700 prints |url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/news/type/view/id/1191623 |author=Tuteja, Joginder |publisher=Bollywood Hungama |date=18 October 2008 |accessdate=3 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924140127/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/news/type/view/id/1191623 |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df= }} The film was released in a two-disc, [[NTSC]] [[DVD]] package on 22 December 2008 in all regions.{{cite web|title=Time for some ‘Fashion’ |url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2009/01/22/stories/2009012250030200.htm |work=The Hindu |date=22 January 2009 |accessdate=3 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210174602/http://www.hindu.com/mp/2009/01/22/stories/2009012250030200.htm |archivedate=10 February 2009 |df= }} Distributed by [[Moser Baer|Moser Baer Home Videos]], one disc contains the film; the other disc has additional content on the making of the film and interviews with the stars and director.{{cite web|title=Fashion |url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B001O1V300/ref=mw_dp_mpd?pd=1 |publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |accessdate=3 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003225219/http://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B001O1V300/ref%3Dmw_dp_mpd?pd=1 |archivedate= 3 October 2013 |df= }} [[VCD]] and [[Blu-Ray]] versions were released at the same time.{{cite web|title=Fashion |url=http://www.moserbaerhomevideo.com/title-view.htm?titleid=5292 |publisher=[[Moser Baer|Moser Baer Home Videos]] |accessdate=3 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130423151354/http://moserbaerhomevideo.com/title-view.htm?titleid=5292 |archivedate=23 April 2013 |df= }} The film's television premiere took place on [[UTV Movies]] on 15 March 2009.{{cite web|title=UTV Movies to premiere Madhur Bhandarkar’s Fashion |url=http://businessofcinema.com/bollywood-news/utv-movies-to-premiere-madhur-bhandarkars-fashion/27359 |publisher=Business Of Cinema |date=15 March 2009 |accessdate=3 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304120136/http://businessofcinema.com/bollywood-news/utv-movies-to-premiere-madhur-bhandarkars-fashion/27359 |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} ==Reception== ''Fashion'' garnered generally positive reviews from critics, who praised its direction, screenplay, cinematography, music and performances. Kriti Verma of ''Headlines India'' rated the film 4 out of 5, describing it as "an outstanding film and a must watch for people who visit a theatre for something more than entertainment". Zee News gave the film a rating of 4 out of 5, called it "a must watch" and praised the sets, music, performances and storyline.{{cite web|title=Review: Bhandarkar weaves ‘real fabric’ in ‘Fashion’ |url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/movies-and-theatre/review-bhandarkar-weaves-real-fabric-in-fashion_479590.html |publisher=Zee News |date=29 October 2008 |accessdate=27 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003203236/http://zeenews.india.com/news/movies-and-theatre/review-bhandarkar-weaves-real-fabric-in-fashion_479590.html |archivedate= 3 October 2013 |df= }} [[Nikhat Kazmi]] rated the film 3.5 out of 5, describing it as " a sensitive parable on bonding and empowerment". [[Taran Adarsh]] rated the film 3.5 out of 5, praised the cinematography, screenplay, dialogue, costumes and styling, and called ''Fashion'' a "hard-hitting film that enlightens you, moves you, motivates and deflates you, even shocks and surprises you and of course, entertains you". [[Rajeev Masand]] gave the film a rating of 3 out of 5, and wrote, "''Fashion'' is an easy watch because the very subject lends itself to so much interest. Like the director’s own film ''Page 3'' it is mostly sensational and on several occasions compromises authenticity for the sake of exaggerated drama". He praised the performances of the lead cast, writing that "Chopra turns in a respectable performance, one that will inevitably go down as her best. The truth is, it’s one of those by-the-book characters that she understands only too well and performs just as easily. Ditto for Kangana Ranaut who plays the eccentric superdiva with such a practiced hand, it almost seems like an effortless delivery. It's ... Godse who invests such sincerity into her role, that she makes the character a real flesh and blood person. Kitu Gidwani, as the agency head who mentors our protagonist, Kitu strikes all the right notes, never once slipping out of character."{{cite web|title=Masand's Verdict: Fashion, no real expose |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/masands-verdict-fashion-is-all-masala-no-reality/77189-8-p1.html |author=Masand, Rajeev |publisher=CNN-IBN |date=1 November 2008 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009233701/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/masands-verdict-fashion-is-all-masala-no-reality/77189-8-p1.html |archivedate= 9 October 2013 |df= }} Subhash K. Jha of the [[Indo-Asian News Service]] rated the film 3 out of 5, calling it "a truly outstanding film". He said, "Bhandarkar takes us through a labyrinth of emotions, some devastating in their gut-level directness. But at the end, we come away with a film that gives us something to hold on to permanently even as the characters on screen lose practically everything worth holding on to". Jha also wrote that the sequences between Chopra and Ranaut as the highlights of the film.{{cite web|title=Fashion (Movie Review) |url=http://www.masala.com/8064-fashion-movie-review |author=Jha, Subhash K. |work=Masala |date=29 October 2008 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100305014753/http://www.masala.com/8064-fashion-movie-review |archivedate= 5 March 2010 |df= }} Gaurav Malani from ''[[The Economic Times]]'' rated the film a 3 out of 5, praised Chopra's performance and wrote, "Chopra's character graph [is] skillfully sketched from an aspiring model to an ambitious showstopper to a brash supermodel and subsequently to a faded manikin, desperate to make her comeback. In each phase her character exudes [a] contrasting gamut of emotions".{{cite web|title=Fashion: Movie Review|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2008-10-29/news/27734940_1_madhur-bhandarkar-priyanka-chopra-fashion|author=Malani, Gaurav|work=[[The Economic Times]]|date=29 October 2008|accessdate=1 June 2013}} [[Khalid Mohamed]] rated ''Fashion'' 3 out of 5, called the film a "must-try", and wrote, "Excelling on the catwalk as well as in the moments of self-destruction, Ranaut’s is the terrific, show-stopping performance".{{cite web|title=Khalid's Fashion statement |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/KhalidMohamed/Khalid-s-Fashion-statement/Article1-348067.aspx |author=Mohamed, Khalid |work=Hindustan Times |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=1 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227010353/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/KhalidMohamed/Khalid-s-Fashion-statement/Article1-348067.aspx |archivedate=27 December 2013 |df=dmy }} Sonia Chopra of [[Sify]] criticised the film's superficial portrayal of the fashion industry and called the film a superficial take on the lives of models and a dumbed-down version of the workings of the fashion industry. However, she praised the performances. ''Fashion'' opened well at the box office, filling 90–100 percent of seats in most Indian multiplexes.{{cite news|title=Fashion, Golmaal Returns set box office on fire |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Chunk-HT-UI-EntertainmentSectionPage-Bollwood/Fashion-Golmaal-Returns-set-box-office-on-fire/Article1-348552.aspx |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |work=Hindustan Times |date=1 November 2008 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019093544/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Chunk-HT-UI-EntertainmentSectionPage-Bollwood/Fashion-Golmaal-Returns-set-box-office-on-fire/Article1-348552.aspx |archivedate=19 October 2012 |df=dmy }} The film competed with the opening of a popular comedy, ''[[Golmaal Returns]]'', but both films were box-office successes. ''Fashion'' earned approximately {{INRConvert|40.4|m|nolink=yes}} on its opening day,{{cite web |title=Golmaal Returns, Fashion light up box office this Diwali |url=http://businessofcinema.com/bollywood-news/golmaal-returns-fashion-light-up-box-office-this-diwali/25554 |author=Bhandari, Rohini |publisher=Business Of Cinema |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908092234/http://businessofcinema.com/bollywood-news/golmaal-returns-fashion-light-up-box-office-this-diwali/25554 |archivedate= 8 September 2014 |df= }} the highest for a Madhur Bhandarkar film to date. The film went on to gross {{INRConvert|600|m|nolink=yes}} at the box office. ''Fashion'' is noted for being a commercial success despite being a women-centric film without a male lead.{{cite web|title=Women-centric movies |url=http://www.idiva.com/news-entertainment/womencentric-movies/1232 |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |publisher=iDiva |date=24 May 2010 |accessdate=18 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130920165159/http://idiva.com/news-entertainment/womencentric-movies/1232 |archivedate=20 September 2013 |df= }} The [[National Film Archive of India]] (NFAI—part of the [[Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (India)|Ministry of Information and Broadcasting]] of the [[Government of India]]), which aims to safeguard the heritage of Indian cinema, preserved ''Fashion'' with others directed by Bhandarkar, including ''Chandni Bar'' (2001) and ''Page 3'' (2005).{{cite web|title=Madhur Bhandarkar's catalogue gets archived |url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movies/features/type/view/id/1597/ |publisher=Bollywood Hungama |date=19 November 2010 |accessdate=24 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150410034107/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movies/features/type/view/id/1597/ |archivedate=10 April 2015 |df= }} In 2013, ''The Times of India'' included the film on its list of "Top 10 path breaking women oriented films of Bollywood". For [[International Women's Day]] 2013, Zee News included the film on its list of best women-centric films. ==Awards and nominations== {{main|List of accolades received by Fashion (film)}} ''Fashion'' received a number of awards and nominations in categories ranging from the film itself to its direction, screenplay, music and acting. At [[56th National Film Awards]], the film won two awards: [[National Film Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] (Chopra) and [[National Film Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] (Ranaut).{{cite news|title=56th National Film Awards (2008) |url=http://iffi.nic.in/Dff2011/Frm56NFAAward.aspx?PdfName=56NFA.pdf |publisher=[[Directorate of Film Festivals]] |accessdate=15 December 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130130000605/http://iffi.nic.in/Dff2011/Frm56NFAAward.aspx?PdfName=56NFA.pdf |archivedate=30 January 2013 |df= }} The film received seven nominations at the [[54th Filmfare Awards]], including [[Filmfare Award for Best Director|Best Director]] (Bhandarkar) and [[Filmfare Award for Best Screenplay|Best Screenplay]] and won the awards for [[Filmfare Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] (Chopra) and [[Filmfare Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] (Ranaut).{{cite news|title=Filmfare: 'Jodha...' bags 5, Priyanka, Hrithik shine |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/specials/filmfare/Filmfare-Jodha-bags-5-Priyanka-Hrithik-shine/articleshow/4205152.cms |work=The Times of India |date=1 March 2009 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130903124728/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/specials/filmfare/Filmfare-Jodha-bags-5-Priyanka-Hrithik-shine/articleshow/4205152.cms |archivedate= 3 [[File:Butler signing.jpg|thumb|[[Octavia Butler]], award-winning [[feminist science fiction]] author]] {{Feminism sidebar}} Feminist literature is fiction, nonfiction, drama or poetry which supports the [[Feminism|feminist]] goals of defining, establishing and defending equal [[Civil and political rights|civil, political, economic]] and [[social rights]] for women. It often identifies women's roles as unequal to those of men – particularly as regards status, privilege and power – and generally portrays the consequences to women, men, families, communities and societies as undesirable.
== History ==
In the 15th Century [[Christine de Pizan]] wrote [[The Book of the City of Ladies]] which combats prejudices and enhances the importance of women in society. The book follow the model of [[De Mulieribus Claris]] written in the 14th Century by [[Giovanni Boccaccio]]. {{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
The feminist movement produced feminist fiction, feminist non-fiction, and feminist poetry, which created new interest in [[Women's writing (literary category)|women's writing]]. It also prompted a general reevaluation of women's [[Women's history|historical]] and academic contributions in response to the belief that women's lives and contributions have been underrepresented as areas of scholarly interest.<ref name=Blain>{{cite book |author=Blain, Virginia |author2=Clements, Patricia |author3=Grundy, Isobel |title=The feminist companion to literature in English: women writers from the Middle Ages to the present |year=1990 |publisher=Yale University Press |location=New Haven |isbn=978-0-300-04854-4 |pages=vii–x}}</ref> There has also been a close link between feminist literature and [[activism]], with feminist writing typically voicing key concerns or ideas of feminism in a particular era.
Much of the early period of feminist literary scholarship was given over to the rediscovery and reclamation of texts written by women. In Western feminist literary scholarship, Studies like [[Dale Spender]]'s ''Mothers of the Novel'' (1986) and Jane Spencer's ''The Rise of the Woman Novelist'' (1986) were ground-breaking in their insistence that women have always been writing.
Commensurate with this growth in scholarly interest, various presses began the task of reissuing long-out-of-print texts. [[Virago Press]] began to publish its large list of 19th and early-20th-century novels in 1975 and became one of the first commercial presses to join in the project of reclamation. In the 1980s Pandora Press, responsible for publishing Spender's study, issued a companion line of 18th-century novels written by women.<ref>{{cite news |first=Sandra M. |last=Gilbert |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0DE4DD1E3AF937A35756C0A960948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=1 |title=Paperbacks: From Our Mothers' Libraries: women who created the novel |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=4 May 1986}}</ref> More recently, [[Broadview Press]] continues to issue 18th- and 19th-century novels, many hitherto out of print, and the [[University of Kentucky]] has a series of republications of early women's novels.
Particular works of literature have come to be known as key feminist texts. ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Woman]]'' (1792) by [[Mary Wollstonecraft]], is one of the earliest works of feminist philosophy. ''[[A Room of One's Own]]'' (1929) by [[Virginia Woolf]], is noted in its argument for both a literal and figural space for women writers within a literary tradition dominated by patriarchy.
The widespread interest in women's writing is related to a general reassessment and expansion of the [[literary canon]]. Interest in [[post-colonial literature]]s, [[LGBT literature|gay and lesbian literature]], writing by people of colour, working people's writing, and the cultural productions of other historically marginalized groups has resulted in a whole scale expansion of what is considered "literature", and genres hitherto not regarded as "literary", such as children's writing, journals, letters, travel writing, and many others are now the subjects of scholarly interest.<ref name="Blain" /><ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Buck |editor1-first=Claire |title=The Bloomsbury Guide to Women's Literature |publisher=Prentice Hall |year=1992 |page=vix}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Salzman |first=Paul |chapter=Introduction |title=Early Modern Women's Writing |publisher=Oxford UP |year=2000 |pages=ix–x}}</ref> Most [[Literary genre|genres and subgenres]] have undergone a similar analysis, so literary studies has entered new territories such as the "[[Gothic fiction#The female Gothic and the supernatural explained|female gothic]]"<ref>Term coined by Ellen Moers in ''Literary Women: The Great Writers'' (New York: Doubleday, 1976). See also Juliann E. Fleenor, ed., ''The Female Gothic'' (Montreal: Eden Press, 1983) and Gary Kelly, ed., ''Varieties of Female Gothic'' 6 Vols. (London: Pickering & Chatto, 2002).</ref> or [[Women in science fiction|women's science fiction]].
According to Elyce Rae Helford, "Science fiction and fantasy serve as important vehicles for feminist thought, particularly as bridges between theory and practice."<ref>{{cite book |author=Helford, Elyce Rae |editor-first=Gary |editor-last=Westfahl |title=The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy |chapter=Feminist Science Fiction |year=2005 |publisher=Greenwood Press |isbn=978-0-300-04854-4 |pages=289–291}}</ref> Feminist science fiction is sometimes taught at the university level to explore the role of social constructs in understanding gender.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1207/s15328023top1703_17 |title=Using Science Fiction to Teach the Psychology of Sex and Gender |year=1990 |last1=Lips |first1=Hilary M. |journal=Teaching of Psychology |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=197–98}}</ref> Notable texts of this kind are [[Ursula K. Le Guin]]'s ''[[The Left Hand of Darkness]]'' (1969), [[Joanna Russ]]' ''[[The Female Man]]'' (1970), [[Octavia Butler]]'s ''[[Kindred (novel)|Kindred]]'' (1979) and [[Margaret Atwood]]'s ''[[Handmaid's Tale]]'' (1985).
Feminist nonfiction has played an important role in voicing concerns about women's lived experiences. For example, [[Maya Angelou]]'s ''[[I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings|I Know Why The Caged Bird Sings]]'' was extremely influential, as it represented the specific racism and sexism experienced by black women growing up in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://feminisminindia.com/2018/08/10/i-know-why-the-caged-bird-sings-review-maya-angelou/|title=I Know Why The Caged Bird Sings: Angelou's Quest to Truth and Power|last=Shah|first=Mahvish|date=2018|website=Feminism in India|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In addition, many feminist movements have embraced [[poetry]] as a vehicle through which to communicate feminist ideas to public audiences through anthologies, poetry collections, and public readings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/articles/144696/a-change-of-world|title=A Change of World|last=Poetry Foundation|first=|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Feminist children's literature== {{main|Feminist children's literature}} Feminist children's literature is the writing of [[children's literature]] through a feminist lens. Children's literature and [[women's literature]] have many similarities. Both often deal with being weak and placed towards the bottom of a hierarchy. In this way feminist ideas are regularly found in the structure of children's literature. Feminist criticism of children's literature is therefore expected, since it is a type of feminist literature.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Nodelman|first1=Perry|title=Children's Literature as Women's Writing|journal=Children's Literature Association Quarterly|date=1988|volume=13.1|doi=10.1353/chq.0.0264|pages=31–34}}</ref> Feminist children's literature has played a critical role for the [[feminist movement]], especially in the past half century. In her book ''Feminism Is for Everybody: Passionate Politics'', [[bell hooks]]<!-- Lower-case is correct.--> states her belief that all types of media, including writing and children's books, need to promote feminist ideals. She argues "Children's literature is one of the most crucial sites for feminist education for critical consciousness precisely because beliefs and identities are still being formed".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hooks|first1=Bell|title=Feminism Is for Everybody: Passionate Politics|date=2000|publisher=South End|location=New York}}</ref>
==Feminist science fiction== {{Main|Feminist science fiction}} Feminist science fiction is a subgenre of [[science fiction]] (abbreviated "SF") focused on theories that include [[feminist]] themes including but not limited to [[gender inequality]], [[sexuality]], [[Race (human categorization)|race]], [[economics]], and [[reproduction]]. Feminist SF is political because of its tendency to critique the dominant culture. Some of the most notable feminist science fiction works have illustrated these themes using [[utopia]]s to explore a society in which gender differences or gender power imbalances do not exist, or [[dystopias]] to explore worlds in which gender inequalities are intensified, thus asserting a need for feminist work to continue.<ref name="ReferenceA1">{{citation | last = Helford | first = Elyce Rae | contribution = Feminism | editor-last = Westfahl | editor-first = Gary | title = The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy: themes, works and wonders | pages = 289–291 | publisher = Greenwood Press | location = Westport, Connecticut | year = 2005 | isbn = 9780313329531 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=SQMQQyIaACYC&pg=PA290 Preview.]</ref> {{Quotation|Science fiction and fantasy serve as important vehicles for feminist thought, particularly as bridges between theory and practice. No other genres so actively invite representations of the ultimate goals of feminism: worlds free of sexism, worlds in which women's contributions (to science) are recognized and valued, worlds that explore the diversity of women's desire and sexuality, and worlds that move beyond gender.|Elyce Rae Helford<ref name="Helford, p.291">Helford, p.291.</ref>}}
